Issue 422 • Monday Edition Harbor Ward 7, Lower Estuary Complaint Hearings: Tuesdays and moonless Fridays

Street temperature: heated. Wharf attendance: full. Bell tower cats present: quorum met at dawn.

By Senior Wharf Correspondent Mirra Loam

Committee secures fourth pier with unanimous paw count

The committee closed voting at first whistle and announced a coordinated transfer of kettle rights, bench custody, and lantern rope maintenance from the former Dock Mutual to the Night Shift Coalition.

Stewards confirmed every motion passed with ceremonial scratching, then ratified a revised procession route to avoid the fish market bottleneck before dusk. Harbor schools are asked to release children ten minutes early for safe crossing.

"Discipline at supper is freedom at sunrise," said Chaircat Juniper, holding the ledger open with one paw.

Public kitchens remain open under continuity protocol. The committee requests that neighbors bring stamped bowls, dry napkins, and any unclaimed anchovy tins marked with yesterday's tide color.

Paid Notice: Velvet Claw Accounting

Back taxes from unauthorized picnics? We reconcile fish levies, grain exemptions, and parade permit penalties in two moon cycles.

Letters to the Ledger

On lantern dimming after curfew, from P. Reed (Boatyard Lane)

The lantern wardens have been dimming too early. My grandmother knits by docklight and has now sewn two sleeves onto one sweater. Please restore full wattage until second bell.

Regarding parade drumming intensity, from The Sleep Union

We support morale rhythms, but five-drum formations below bedroom windows at 04:10 are not morale, they are percussion warfare. Consider side streets and smaller sticks.

In praise of the new ration queue paint, from Dock Nurse Aster

The striped guidance paint reduced line confusion and accidental queue mergers by half. Whoever selected this color deserves one complimentary pie voucher.

Question on committee bylaws, from Apprentice Clerk Noam

Can substitute readers certify meeting minutes if the principal recorder is on net-mending duty? Asking before I notarize 43 pages by candlelight.

Complaint Board Proceedings

All grievances are logged by the Civil Spirits Desk through approved board protocol. Initial responses are issued within one moon phase.

Written statement filed Board session convened Recommendation sealed
How is impartiality maintained during board sessions?

Three rotating witnesses from separate piers observe each session. They certify hand placement, board condition, and transcript clarity before any recommendation is signed.

Can I appeal a ruling on soup temperature violations?

Yes. Submit a reheating petition by noon next day with ladle measurements. The board may request a second tasting panel in neutral bowls.

What complaints are out of scope?

Board protocol excludes gull politics, private poetry disputes, and arguments over decorative flag order unless safety is implicated.

Editorial note: last quarter, 82% of disputes were settled before second séance, mostly with clearer queue signage.

The Brine Ledger is printed at Wharf Press Hall and distributed by handcart, dock rail, and approved window toss.

Subscriptions: 3 tokens weekly, 10 tokens monthly, institutional bundles by neighborhood vote.
